content:
✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Good problem and test cases.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is awesome for a clash problem, comrade.

No validator is actually checking the same thing as the sample test suggest by 21stCenturyPeon. None of them contain a number that is duplicated in the output, although two tests do contain a duplicated number.  Great clash!

Since no names is usually better than wrong or bad names, I'd suggest renaming “3 elements” to “sorted”, and “10 elements” to “reverse sorted”.  The “sequences of 5 numbers” is instead just a single element, so either the validator is not what you intended or you misnamed it.

Additionally, the parenthesis (less than the previous element) may be confusing. I can imagine people think “previous” refers to the last checked element, instead of the previous `max_val`.  Not sure how to improve that, maybe “previous SORTED element” works?

Also, why not mention this is an O(n) algorithm, the main selling point of Stalin Sort!

Missing test case: element[x] == element[x+1]: by the rules of the statement ("removing any that are... less than the previous element"), elements {1,3,2,3,5} should output "1 3 3 5".

Or, add a constraint that all [[element]] values are different.

Good clash-fodder, though.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Interesting and fun contribution for a Clash of Code.
Maybe just make test and validator match each other to be equivalent.
It looks like these are all test but don't has its equivalent validator (example : 10 and 100 elements, large numbers with min and max).
Just duplicate your tests with different values for validators and this would be great !

In addition to 5DN1l Edits
Goal 
Please state what is to happen if n =0

Constraints 
swap the "<=" to "≤"

Cases
N = 0 still must have an element given even if not run

also was Fun CoC good job

Input
* Line 1: Please change "Given" to "An integer".

* Line 1: Please change "sort" to "sorted".

* Please change "a sequences of element to be sort" to "An integer [[element]] in the list to be sorted".

Output
* Please change "element" to "list of elements".

Cases
* Each pair of test and validator should be similar. Hence:

   • Please add a pair of cases where n = 0. Please replace the original "None" validator with a validator similar to "large number" test.

   • Please add a validator similar to "Just one" test to pair up with it.

   • Please add a test similar to "sequences of 5 number" validator to pair up with it.

   • Suggest to revise the case names and use the plural form of words to replace the singular forms where appropriate.

Thanks.
